results.notes:
Code: Bot_463/2010_IMG2710 and Bot_464/2010_DSC5400

Habitat: mixed wood, Picea abies and Fagus sylvatica dominant trees; locally almost flat terrain, bottom of the valley; calcareous ground; almost in shade; partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies, average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 5-7 deg C, elevation 820 m (2.700 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: totally rotten, moss overgrown Picea abies stump.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, Zadnjica side-valley, near Stružnik place, next to the dirt road to the end of the valley, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC

Comments: Tricholomopsis rutilans can hardly be confused with other species in the field. Beautifully yellow-reddish colored mushroom has abundant and large (up to 140 microns long) cheilocystidia, which can be seen even without microscope with any magnifying glass. The mushroom is generally quite common although not in the Trenta valley. A single fruitbody has been found. Smell and taste mild, indistinct; SP white.

Nikon D700 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8 and Canon G11, 6.1-30mm/f2.8-4.5

results.notes:
Growing from an oak branch, there is plenty of conifer debris in the general area yet they were only growing on this piece of oak which seems odd for a sp. that prefers conifer.The only other time I have seen one of these small gymnopilus on something other than conifer was this single fruit seen here http://mushroomobserver.org/286558?q=AlIF the rest of that obs was found on conifer so its possibly a mixed collection. Strangely enough the fruit in question from that obs has an extremely similar look to the cap as the fruit from this obs.

Perhaps they are all the same, hard to say for sure without further investigation.

results.notes:
Almost as soon as the paper describing this new genus and species came out, Paula (longtooth) was showing me one of her regular sites to find this extraordinary fungus, which she had observed before the paper was conceived. The specimens she collected and sent to the authors contributed toward New York being included in its distribution. Late in the season though we were, a single, somewhat deteriorated individual was found on top of a moss-covered stump amidst a grove of eastern hemlocks.

I noticed a number of dark red, spherical bodies throughout the mount. I am unsure as to whether they are fungal in origin or belong to the insect. They are not mentioned in the paper. A focus stacked micrograph shows a cluster of them altogether, and this video shows their varying depths in the tissue.

Host: adult polydesmid millipede

Habitat: mixed forest (oak, maple, beech, birch, white pine & eastern hemlock) with vernal pools, south/southwest of water feature (Mad River) surrounded by suburban development

Ecoregion: Eastern Great Lakes Lowland Forest (NA0407)

Collectors: D. Newman & P. DeSanto

results.notes:
Growing gregariously in disturbed soil at the edge of a parking lot under oaks (Quercus sect. Quercus and Quercus sect. Lobatae). Some growing caespitose in clusters of up to 3. Caps viscid and hygrophanous, fading to a lighter brown. Odor raphanoid. Taste farinose. Cortina appeared to be absent. Context off-white to opaque above the gills and in the center of the stem. Stems pruinose. Gill edges white fimbriate. Gills entire. Largest basidiocarps measured weren’t included in the photo since they weren’t in very good condition.

results.notes:
Growing all around on the trunk of a dead, standing oak as well as over Armillaria rhizomorphs on the trunk. Odor a bit pungent but not especially distinctive. White rot. 5% KOH light brown on teeth. No significant reaction under an ultraviolet flashlight. All structures inamyloid. Monomitic with clamped generative hyphae. Cystidia absent. Unbranched hyphidia abundant and projecting past the basidia. Basidia clavate. Spores hyaline, smooth and thick-walled. results.notes:
A large fruiting area in a grassy clearing of A. muscaria subsp. flavivolvata beneath Douglas fir and western hemlock that I have been monitoring all season. The original flush was stalled by heavy snowfall a week or so ago. New fruiting bodies/buttons still popping here.

Note: B. edulis var grand-edulis are fruiting within 20 feet of this large shiro of Amanita. This is the third time in the last two seasons where the anecdotal reports of A. muscaria and B. edulis fruiting simultaneously from the same mycorrhizal host has been personally confirmed. This interaction and co-mingling mycorrhizal relationship of two separate species together has been evident with this group of trees for not only the amanita and porcini here, but also for co-fruitings of Suillus and Gomphidious, in addition to the earlier Chalciporus piperatus and Amanita muscaria subs. flavivolvata observed earlier here in the season.

Elevation: Sea level.

results.notes:
A single, beautiful fruiting body of B. edulis var grandedulis directly beneath Western hemlock. Light pinkish red tones on cap, perfect reticulation at apex of stem(white), bulbous stem base, mycorrhizal with conifers-especially pine and fir(NOT OAK).

I have been monitoring the nearby abundant fruiting of Amanita muscaria subs. flavivolvata(within feet of this porcini) for over a month now. I always am on the look out for porcini whenever I encounter large groupings of A. muscaria. Nice to have this association of species as indicators confirmed yet again this season. Other personally confirmed/documented associations of species with this location(between the same two hemlock and Doug fir) are Suillus caerulescens with Gomphidious subroseus and Chalciporus piperatus with Amanita muscaria subs. flavivolvata. A ton of mycorrhizal activity in this mature, 2nd growth conifer dominant habitat.

Elevation: Sea level.

Added images of the collected B. edulis var grandedulis and A. muscaria subs. flavivolvata together for size and comparison of fruiting occurrence and proximity to one another(within 20 feet of each other-directly beneath the W. hemlock).

results.notes: Found what I was pretty confident was P.allenii/cyanofriscosa. Growing on chips in soil, not log. Stem mostly white, no evidence of annulus though specimens are somewhat old, cap and stem bruising consistently blue. Spore print, however, was more dark brown than purple-black and when i printed on black paper they looked eeriely rusty-brown or at least with a rusty-sheen. Pretty confident but wanted to make sure I don’t have a masquerading Galerina marginata

results.notes:
All white, ragged, shaggy stipe, ventricose, tapering at base(slightly bruising brown where handled)-smoky gray/purple veil remnant towards apex. Caps- are dome shaped, viscous, glutinous, light brownish to white, with incurved margins, purple gray remnants on margin(similar to behavior of mature H. fasciculare and H. capnoides ). Spore print-purple/gray. Odor- lightly fungaloid, pleasant. Gills crowded with short alternating sections. Gill edges NOT RAGGED-as with Neolentinus, Lentinus , etc. Fruiting from buried conifer wood(Douglas fir).

Possible alba or albino variant of H. capnoides or an un-described collection/species of Pholiota.

Elevation: 2200ft.

Collected three specimens for microscopy, herbarium storage and further study.
results.location_name: Gifford Pinchot National Forest, Washington, USA

results.notes:
Habitat: Growing in moss/leaf litter on a slope in dense mixed hardwood/pine forest in Northwest Georgia.

Gills: pink with yellow to orange edges, with lamellulae, slightly decurrent

Stipe: smooth, dark orange to pale yellow (near base). slightly oily residue from handling.

Cap: Moist but not overly viscid. Very fragile. 1) Younger specimens – ovate, scarlet red with orange undertones. Edges are yellow to orange. 2) Older specimens – more plane shaped (some with wavy edges). Some are colored red with orange edges while others have faded to yellow or orange (centrally).

Spore print: white.
results.location_name: Oakman, Georgia, USA

It was the only one around it in the area I could find.

results.notes:
Growing alone from the base of a large oak

Cap appeared to be faintly striate but the cold wind dried it out I guess. Dark squamules in the center.

Stem white, hollow/slightly stuffed with white basal mycelium.

Gills looked white from the underside but after cutting it in half the faces looked greyish, looks nearly free or attached by a slight notch, I cant really tell. Attempting a spore print but it looks pretty dried out from the cold wind, will update later if it drops a print.

Similar odor to a spermatic inocybe but different, fairly unpleasant.

Possibly a pluteus? I cant tell if this is considered “free gills” from my cross section, input on that greatly appreciated.
